Formulae.Title: The Definition of Kinetic Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The kinetic energy of an object is proportional to the mass of that object and its speed squared.

Identifiers.Definition: is the kinetic energy of the object
is the mass of the object
is the speed of the object

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an object of mass $m$ that is accelerated from rest by a constant force of magnitude $F$. The work done by the force to accelerate the object over a distance $x$ is given by
$$W = \int_{0}^{x} F \mathrm{d} x$$
Force is defined as the rate of change of momentum.
$$F = \frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} t}$$
Since the momentum of an object is just the product of its mass and velocity, this can be written as
$$F = \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t} (mv)$$
The mass of the object is constant, so this can be written as
$$F = m \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t} (v) = m \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}$$
Therefore
$$W = \int_{0}^{x} m \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} \mathrm{d} x = m \int_{0}^{x} \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} \mathrm{d} x$$
Using integration by substitution, this becomes
$$W = m \int_{0}^{t} \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t} \mathrm{d} t$$
$$W = m \int_{0}^{t} \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t} v \mathrm{d} t$$
Using integration by substitution again, this becomes
$$W = m \int_{0}^{v} v \mathrm{d} v$$
Solving the integral, we get
$$W = m \times \frac{1}{2} v^{2}$$
$$W = \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$$
Thus the kinetic energy of an object is the minimum amount of work that must be done in order to accelerate that object to that speed.

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics
The Cambridge Handbook of Physics Formulas

Formulae.Title: The Elastic Potential Energy of an Ideal Spring
Formulae.Interpretation: The potential energy stored in a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement of the spring from its equilibrium position.

Identifiers.Definition: is the elastic potential energy stored in the spring
is the spring constant of the spring
is the displacement of the spring from its equilibrium position

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an ideal spring with a spring constant $k$. The magnitude of the restoring force exerted by the spring when it has an extension of $x$ is
$$F = kx$$
The work done to extend the spring from its equilibrium position to $x_{1}$ is the integral of the restoring force of the spring over the distance that the force is exerted.
$$W = \int_{0}^{x_{1}} F(x) \mathrm{d} x$$
$$W = \int_{0}^{x_{1}} kx \mathrm{d} x$$
Solving this integral, we get
$$W = \frac{1}{2} k x^{2}$$
The elastic potential energy of a spring is the minimum amount of work that it takes to extend the spring by a given length.

Formulae.Title: The Escape Velocity Formula
Formulae.Interpretation: The speed that an object must have in order to escape the gravitational pull of a spherical, non-rotating body is dependent on the mass of the body and the radius of the body.

Identifiers.Definition: is the escape speed if the object moves radially away from the body

is the mass of the body
is the radius of the body

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider a large, spherical, non-rotating object A with mass $M$ and radius $R$, and a second, smaller object B with mass $m$. Object B is initially on the surface of object A.
The gravitational potential energy of object B on the surface of A is
$$E_{G} = - \frac{G M m}{R}$$
In order for object B to be moved from its initial position to an infinite distance away from object A, it needs to be given an amount of kinetic energy equal to $\frac{G M m}{R}$.
$$\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} = \frac{G M m}{R}$$
This equation can be rearranged to give us the escape speed of object B.
$$\frac{1}{2} v^{2} = \frac{G M}{R}$$
$$v^{2} = \frac{2 G M}{R}$$
$$v = \sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}$$

are the generalised coordinates

Formulae.Title: The Gravitational Field Strength inside a Planet
Formulae.Interpretation: For a spherical astronomical object of uniform density, the gravitational field strength at a point inside the object is directly proportional to the density of the object multiplied by the distance between the point and the object's centre of mass.

Identifiers.Definition: is the acceleration due to gravity
is the Universal Gravitational Constant
is the density of the planet
is the radial distance from the object's centre of mass

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider a spherical object $O$ that has a radius $R$ and a constant density $\rho$.
Also consider a sphere $S$, the centre of which is at the centre of $O$, and which has a radius $r < R$. The mass of $O$ that is enclosed by $S$ is given by
$$M = \int \rho \mathrm{d}V$$
Since the density of $O$ is constant, $\rho$ can be taken outside the integral.
$$M = \rho \int \mathrm{d}V$$
The integral is then just equal to the volume of sphere $S$, which is equal to $\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$.
$$M = \rho \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$$
This can be substituted into Gauss' Law for Gravity.
$$\oint \textbf{g} \cdot \mathrm{d} \textbf{A} = -4 \pi GM$$
$$\oint \textbf{g} \cdot \mathrm{d} \textbf{A} = -4 \pi G \rho \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$$
The above integral can be simplified. Since $O$ and $S$ are spherically symmetric, the direction of the acceleration due to gravity is always antiparallel to the normal to the surface element $\mathrm{d} \textbf{A}$. Therefore, the integral can be written in terms of scalar values of $g$ and $\mathrm{d} A$.
$$-\oint g \mathrm{d} A = -4 \pi G \rho \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$$
The magnitude of the acceleration is also constant for constant $r$, so $g$ can be taken outside the integral.
$$-g \oint \mathrm{d} A = -4 \pi G \rho \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$$
The surface area of $S$ is $4 \pi r^{2}$, so
$$-g 4 \pi r^{2} = -4 \pi G \rho \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}$$
This can be simplified to
$$g = \frac{4}{3} G \pi \rho r$$
which is the acceleration due to gravity at all points on the surface of $S$, and thus the acceleration due to gravity at a radial distance $r$ away from the centre of mass of $O$.

Formulae.Title: The Projectile Range Formula
Formulae.Interpretation: The distance, $R$, that a projectile that is launched from the ground will travel before it hits the ground again depends on the launch speed, $v_{0}$, the angle between the initial velocity of the projectile and the ground, $\theta$, and the acceleration due to gravity, $g$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the horizontal distance that the projectile will travel
is the launch speed of the projectile
is the angle between the initial velocity of the projectile and the ground
is the acceleration due to gravity

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an object that is initially at a position $x = 0$ and $y = 0$ (the object is on the ground).
At a time $t = 0$, the object is launched in the positive x direction with a speed $v_{0}$ and at an angle $\theta$ to the x-axis (the ground).
Using trigonometry, we can determine that the x and y components of the object's initial velocity are given by
$$v_{0_{x}} = v_{0} \sin(\theta)$$
$$v_{0_{y}} = v_{0} \cos(\theta)$$
The object is in a uniform gravitational field of field strength $g$ in the negative y direction. The object therefore has an acceleration of $-g$ along the y-axis, and an acceleration of $0$ along the x-axis.
The x-position of the object at a given time $t$ after it is launched is given by
$$s_{x}(t) = s_{0_{x}} + v_{0_{x}} t + \frac{1}{2} a_{x} t^{2}$$
Since
$$s_{0_{x}} = 0$$
$$a_{x} = 0$$
the above equation can be simplified to
$$s_{x}(t) = 0 + v_{0_{x}} t + \frac{1}{2} \times 0 \times t^{2}$$
$$s_{x}(t) = v_{0_{x}} t$$
The y-position of the object at a given time $t$ after it is launched is given by
$$s_{y}(t) = s_{0_{y}} + v_{0_{y}} t + \frac{1}{2} a_{y} t^{2}$$
Since
$$s_{0_{y}} = 0$$
$$a_{y} = -g$$
the above equation can be simplified to
$$s_{y}(t) = 0 + v_{0_{y}} t - \frac{1}{2} g t^{2}$$
$$s_{y}(t) = v_{0_{y}} t - \frac{1}{2} g t^{2}$$
The projectile hits the ground again when $s_{y}(t) = 0$ (on the condition that $t \neq 0$). By substituting this value into the above equation, we can find the time after which the projectile hits the ground.
$$0 = v_{0_{y}} t - \frac{1}{2} g t^{2}$$
$$v_{0_{y}} t = \frac{1}{2} g t^{2}$$
$$v_{0_{y}} = \frac{1}{2} g t$$
$$t = \frac{2 v_{0_{y}}}{g}$$
This expression for the time at which the projectile hits the ground can be substituted into the expression for the x-position of the particle given above to give us the range of the projectile.
$$R = \frac{2 v_{0_{x}} v_{0_{y}}}{g}$$
By substituting in the expressions for the x and y components of the velocity given above, this becomes
$$R = \frac{2 v_{0}^{2} \sin(\theta) \cos(\theta)}{g}$$
Using the trigonometric identity
$$\sin(2 \theta) = 2 \sin(\theta) \cos(\theta)$$
this can be simplified to
$$R = \frac{v_{0}^{2} \sin(2 \theta)}{g}$$

Formulae.Title: The Relativistic Energy-Momentum Relation
Formulae.Interpretation: The total relativistic energy of an object can be expressed in terms of its relativistic momentum and its rest mass.

Identifiers.Definition: is the total relativistic energy of the object
is the relativistic momentum of the object
is the speed of light in free space
is the rest mass of the object

Formulae.Derivation:
The relativistic momentum of an object that has a rest mass $m_{0}$ and which is moving at a speed $v$ relative to an observer is given by
$$p = \gamma m_{0} v$$
We can rearrange this using the following identity involving the Lorentz Factor
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = \gamma^{2} - 1$$
where the Lorentz Factor, $\gamma$, is
$$\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - \beta^{2}}}$$
and $\beta = \frac{v}{c}$. This identity can be proven as follows
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = \gamma^{2} (\beta^{2} - 1 + 1)$$
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = \gamma^{2} (\beta^{2} - 1) + \gamma^{2}$$
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = - \gamma^{2} (1 - \beta^{2}) + \gamma^{2}$$
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = - \frac{1 - \beta^{2}}{1 - \beta^{2}} + \gamma^{2}$$
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = -1 + \gamma^{2}$$
$$\gamma^{2} \beta^{2} = \gamma^{2} - 1$$
We take the above relativistic momentum equation, and divide both sides by $c$.
$$\frac{p}{c} = \gamma m_{0} \frac{v}{c}$$
Then we can change $\frac{v}{c}$ to just $\beta$.
$$\frac{p}{c} = \gamma m_{0} \beta$$
If we square both sides we can then use the above identity.
$$\frac{p^{2}}{c^{2}} = \gamma^{2} m_{0}^{2} \beta^{2}$$
$$\frac{p^{2}}{c^{2}} = \gamma^{2} m_{0}^{2} - m_{0}^{2}$$
Then we multiply both sides by $c^{4}$.
$$p^{2}c^{2} = \gamma^{2} m_{0}^{2} c^{4} - m_{0}^{2} c^{4}$$
The total relativistic energy of an object is given by
$$E = \gamma m_{0} c^{2}$$
This can be substituted into the previous equation.
$$p^{2}c^{2} = E^{2} - m_{0}^{2} c^{4}$$
This can be rearranged to give the momentum-energy equation.
$$E^{2} = p^{2}c^{2} + m_{0}^{2} c^{4}$$

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Distance as a Function of Time for Constant Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the distance travelled by that object as a function of time is given by a quadratic formula with respect to time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the position of the object at a time $t$
is the position of the object at time $t = 0$
is the initial velocity of the object
is the acceleration of the object
is time

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an object that is moving with a constant acceleration, $a$. The velocity of that object at time $t$ is equal to the integral of the acceleration over time.
$$v(t) = \int a \mathrm{d} t$$
This is equal to the constant acceleration multiplied by the time, plus a constant velocity - the initial velocity.
$$v(t) = at + u$$
The position of the object at time $t$ is equal to the integral of the velocity over time.
$$s(t) = \int v(t) \mathrm{d} t$$
$$s(t) = \int (at + u) \mathrm{d} t$$
Solving this integral gives
$$s(t) = \frac{1}{2} a t^{2} + ut + s_{0}$$

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an object that is moving with a constant acceleration, $a$. The velocity of that object at time $t$ is equal to the integral of the acceleration over time.
$$v(t) = \int a \mathrm{d} t$$
This is equal to the constant acceleration multiplied by the time, plus a constant velocity - the initial velocity.
$$v(t) = at + u$$

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Final Velocity as a Function of Distance for Constant Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the square of the object's final velocity is equal to the square of its initial velocity plus two times the acceleration times the distance travelled.

Identifiers.Definition: is the final velocity of the object
is the initial velocity of the object
is the acceleration of the object
is the distance travelled by the object

Formulae.Derivation:
Consider an object of mass $m$ that is moving with a constant acceleration, $a$. At the start of its motion, the object has an initial velocity, $u$. The kinetic energy at the start of its motion is therefore
$$E_{K, u} = \frac{1}{2} m u^{2}$$
At a time $t$, the object has a final velocity $v$. The kinetic energy at time $t$ is therefore
$$E_{K, v} = \frac{1}{2} m v^{2}$$
Since the object has mass and is accelerating, it is experiencing a force, $F$. As the acceleration is constant, the force is also constant, and is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration.
$$F = ma$$
The force does work on the object between the object's initial and final positions. The amount of work done by the force is equal to the integral of the force over the distance that the object moves.
$$W = \int F \mathrm{d} x$$
$$W = \int ma \mathrm{d} x$$
Since both the mass and the acceleration are constant, the $ma$ can be brought outside the integral.
$$W = ma \int \mathrm{d} x$$
The integral is then just equal to the total distance moved by the object, $s$.
$$W = mas$$
The final kinetic energy of the object is equal to the initial kinetic energy of the object plus the work done in accelerating the object.
$$\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} = \frac{1}{2} m u^{2} + mas$$
This equation can be simplified by dividing each term by the mass of the object, and then multiplying each term by 2.
$$\frac{1}{2} v^{2} = \frac{1}{2} u^{2} + as$$
$$v^{2} = u^{2} + 2as$$

Constants.Title: The Avogadro Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Avogadro Constant is the number of constituent particles that are contained in the amount of substance given by one mole.

References.Title: Avogadro constant

Constants.Title: The Bohr Magneton
Constants.Interpretation: The Bohr Magneton is a physical constant for expressing the magnetic moment of an electron caused by its orbital or spin angular momentum.

References.Title: Bohr magneton

Constants.Title: The Bohr Radius
Constants.Interpretation: The Bohr Radius is a physical constant that is approximately equal to the most probable distance between the nucleus and the electron in a hydrogen atom in its ground state.

References.Title: Bohr radius

Constants.Title: The Boltzmann Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Boltzmann Constant is a physical constant that relates the average kinetic energy of particles in a gas to the temperature of the gas.

References.Title: Boltzmann constant

Constants.Title: The Coulomb Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Coulomb Constant is a constant of proportionality in the equations governing electrodynamics.

References.Title: Coulomb's constant

Constants.Title: Elementary Charge
Constants.Interpretation: The Elementary Charge is the charge carried by a single proton, and the magnitude of the charge carried by a single electron.

Constants.Title: The Electron Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Electron Rest Mass is the mass of an electron as measured in the rest frame of an electron.

References.Title: Electron rest mass

Constants.Title: The Faraday Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Faraday Constant is a physical constant that represents the magnitude of electric charge per mole of electrons.

References.Title: Faraday constant

Constants.Title: The Ideal Gas Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Ideal Gas Constant is a physical constant that is equivalent to the Boltzmann Constant but expressed in units of energy per temperature increment per mole.

References.Title: Gas constant

Constants.Title: The Neutron Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Neutron Rest Mass is the mass of a neutron as measured in the rest frame of the neutron.

References.Title: Neutron

Constants.Title: The Permeability of Free Space / The Vacuum Permeability
Constants.Interpretation: The permeability of free space is an ideal physical constant which is the value of magnetic permeability in a classical vacuum.

References.Title: Vacuum permeability

Constants.Title: The Permittivity of Free Space / The Vacuum Permittivity
Constants.Interpretation: The permittivity of free space is an ideal physical constant which is the value of the absolute dielectric permittivity of a classical vacuum.

References.Title: Vacuum permittivity

Constants.Title: The Planck Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Planck Constant is used in the description of a number of physical phenomena, including blackbody radiation, the photoelectric effect, and the uncertainty principle.

References.Title: Planck constant

Constants.Title: The Proton Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Proton Rest Mass is the mass of a proton as measured in the rest frame of a proton.

References.Title: Proton

Constants.Title: The Reduced Planck Constant (the Dirac Constant)
Constants.Interpretation: The Reduced Planck Constant is equal to the Planck Constant divided by $2 \pi$, which is a more convenient value to use in many equations.

References.Title: Planck constant

Constants.Title: The Rydberg Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Rydberg Constant is a physical constant that represents the limiting value of the wavenumber of the lowest-energy photon capable of ionising a hydrogen atom from its ground state.

References.Title: Rydberg constant

Constants.Title: The Speed of Light in Free Space
Constants.Interpretation: The speed of light in free space is the hypothetical 'speed limit' of the universe. Nothing is known to travel faster than this speed.

Constants.Title: The Stefan-Boltzmann Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Stefan-Boltzmann Constant is a physical constant that relates the total energy radiated per unit surface area of a black body across all wavelengths to the temperature of the object.

References.Title: Stefan-Boltzmann constant

Constants.Title: The Unified Atomic Mass Unit
Constants.Interpretation: The Unified Atomic Mass Unit is a standard unit of mass that quantifies mass on an atomic scale. One unified atomic mass unit is approximately equal to the mass of one nucleon.

References.Title: Unified atomic mass unit

Constants.Title: The Universal Gravitational Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The universal gravitational constant is an empirical physical constant used in the calculation of gravitational effects in Newton's Law of Gravitation and Einstein's General Theory of Relativity.

References.Title: Gravitational constant

Constants.Title: The Wien Displacement Constant
